abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome was
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. Nonetheless,
            design flaws made project implementation problematic, and
            the failure of the project to designate responsibility, and
            authority to a specific department at the early stages, was
            conducive to the absence of ownership. This led to a
            significant shift, when implementation responsibility was
            defined, and efficiently handled, and the performance of the
            Borrower, improved dramatically. However, infrequent, and
            inadequate Bank supervision, failed to include training, and
            financial management support, during early critical stages
            of implementation. The lessons learned reinforce once again,
            that technical assistance lending (TAL) instruments, do not
            provide broad strategies to address various weaknesses, or
            systemic problems in critical areas. Thus, it is suggested
            that future TAL projects, could provide procurement clinics,
            and workshops - prior to effectiveness - for participating
            agencies, and stakeholders. The project also conveyed the
            need to establish an annual review process, in order to
            enhance a positive interaction among the Borrower, its
            implementing agencies, and the Bank, to minimize
            implementation difficulties. The need for adequate
            institutional development is addressed, to achieve flawless
            internal controls in reporting requirements, financial
            management, and auditing procedures.
